snippet.textDisplay: As someone with ADHD, even I see my regular doctor about my medication and symptoms that aren't always physical. Sure I first got diagnosed and prescribed medication by a childhood psychiatrist, but it stopped at that. Most of the time my doctor is more than able to give me advice or help me find the right medication for me. I'd even say that I feel more comfortable sharing such things with her, as she's been my doctor pretty much my entire life. Psychiatrists are serious business, and it is also a very big and scary step to take for many people. Even if your doctor is unable to help you, they often have a broad network of specialists in different fields, they can help you get to the right specialist, get you the right help. If you have a good doctor they will always listen and take you seriously.

snippet.textDisplay:
While this all may be true for Dr. Mke, we need to stop and think about the number of family care doctors who are prejudiced against people with mental health issues (studies show that this is not the exception). Some will prescribe a medication, and then sit back and watch the patient gain 60 pounds, blaming them for their "eating and activity level" (yes, this is a real-world example from a family member). Others will stop taking the patient seriously and begin talking mostly to a family member to get information about symptoms, as if the patient is not competent. The same thing happens with pain medications--while a pain specialist will prescribe or recommend a certain course of treatment, the family specialist will be prejudiced against the given patient (due to race, gender, or mental health condition) and fail to treat correctly (again, a real-world example).

In an ideal world, a family health specialist can do what Dr. Mike states--but, in the real world, many PCPs get out of their depth with mental health, pain, or women's health issues (an example--a primary care provider who thinks that polycystic ovarian syndrome does not exist--that the symptoms are simply what happens when a lazy, stupid, non-compliant patient gets fat). While I would not make the sweeping statement that Lady Gaga does, I would say that going to a trained psychiatrist (especially when we are discussing medications which have bad side effects that the primary physician is ignoring because s/he thinks that the medication is more beneficial than harmful) might be life-saving (again, this is an example from a family member who now has a medication-linked condition which might have been avoided and now is life-threatening and will probably wind up as fatal). Further, there is pressure from insurers on PCPs to provide medication as "first line treatment," despite the many negative health effects, rather than more expensive treatments such as behavioral therapy.

I think that this particular video is a bit too idealistic, too apologist considering the number of people who have PCPs who are prejudiced against those with mental health problems, and way too in favor of medication as "first line" treatment.

snippet.textDisplay:
Very refreshing to listen to a level-headed doctor.
I worked for a hot-headed, impatient PCP (I’m a CCMA), and it always seemed like he was very quick to just prescribe medicine and move on to the next patient as quickly as possible.
I completely understand being very busy and having a full schedule

We had a patient come in with what seemed to be a bad infection that made the patient’s lips swell up HUGE. He was in a lot of pain, so the doctor prescribed narcotics and some other meds for the infection- pretty standard. However, the patient came back a few days later and said he had taken ALL of his pain meds already. The doctor was notified that the patient had been abusing his medicine, but the doctor STILL decided to give him a different kind of narcotic. Maybe a week later, we got the news the the patient had over dosed and died.
I’m curious to see what your opinion of this situation is.

snippet.textDisplay: I was diagnosed with PTSD and "Accute Chronic Anxiety Disorder." I have used Clonazepam in short bursts several times in my life just to make it through the day. My current doc got me up to 90x 2mg Clonazepam/30 days for nearly a year. I insisted we ween me down by 10 a month and now I'm down to 50x 2mg/month. Is the 90x a month (not considering tolerance) an indicator of bad medicine? If I don't take the Clonazepam, after about 2 days, I feel like a crack astronaut. No sleep. Irritable. No seizures or twitches, but it's a very raw and uncomfortable time.

snippet.textDisplay: I think both of you are right. It depends on how healthcare is organized and the specific culture of a healthcare system. What Lady Gaga says matches the Spanish healthcare system. Primary care physicians usually refer patients to psychiatrists, and in the meanwhile, they may give patients antianxiety meds. The waiting list doesn't have to be long. It depends on the situation. The patient will see the psychiatrist repeatedly and create a connection. Being referred to a specialist (any type) is common in Spain, and it's one of the countries that rank highest in cost-effectiveness. In other countries, it's the primary care physician who does this (at least for anxiety and depression or cases that aren't complex). This can work too. Anyway, I can see advantages and disadvantages to both systems, and for Lady Gaga, the cons may weigh more.

snippet.textDisplay: My problem with this, and what I don't understand, is why we are considering anti depressants first line treatment? With all of the harms we are learning about xanax and many others, it seems mind blowing that we are still throwing pills at people after a 5 minute discussion with a non specialist. You wouldn't prescribe someone oxy right away because they are in pain, so why are we doing that anti depressants, and others like it, as if it's a cure all? Or even as if we understand a small amount of the long term risks of these. Lady Gaga's point was not that primary care doctors aren't qualified, or that every person should see a psychiatrist, but more that primary care doctors seem to be throwing these pills out without first considering less harmful methods, like therapy, that a specialist might first consider. Or at least I'd hope they would.

snippet.textDisplay: Hi Dr Mike, I hear what you say. When presented in the way that you did it makes sense. But what Lady Gaga said also has truth to it. Many people do not have PCP. They are not even aware that they should develop a relationship with their PCP  so that these kinds of things can get taken care of in a triage fashion like you mention. I talk about this through the lens of the Hispanic population, they don't know how the medical system works in reality <del>same reason a lot of them tend to go to the ER for something that can be seen at urgent care. The problem lies when it comes to government sponsored insurances. The doctors who take these insurances tend to work at free or low cost clinics that end up being overpacked with all kinds of patients. I went in to one after ending up at the ER for dyspnea and anxiety for a follow up and the doctor really only spent about 5 minutes on the problem and immediately wanted to prescribe me anxiolytics without asking anything else other than what a quick questionnaire -risk factor questionnaire</del> scored me at. However she was more interested in how the rest of my body was functioning <del>which yes it is important</del> but wasn't the priority at the time. While I agree that specialities get into their respective fields because of their interest specialty doctors can not ignore the more "basic" cases. You can't help everyone but you can help someone no matter how big or small. I think what Lady Gaga was talking about was the fact that many people get their antidepressants or anxiolytics and that's it nothing else. No referral to a therapist. No referral to a psychiatrist. Or a very quick followup the next visit to "see how they are doing," and that's it. That where the problem lies. You and I both know the importance of dual treatment for mental health and that things like anxiety and depression are best treated with a combination of drugs and some form of therapy. That's what she is alluding to, the fact that all most people are given a lot of times is the drugs and not the therapy which is a very crucial component of treatment. Doctors are seen as a form of authority, so to many people what the doctor says or doesn't say, goes. Many times doctors are more concerned about, let's say a pt's cholesterol levels despite having no indication of high cholesterol, than their chief complaint of depression or anxiety so they just check the box that says tx given for anxiety and move on to the next pt. That's what she's alluding to, and it's more common than you think. It's happened to me, fortunately I know better and I know how the system works because I want to practice medicine at some point in my life, but to others who really don't know better, this happens quite often.

snippet.textDisplay: This makes me so sad, the mental health team in my city is so strained if you need help you either have to be at risk to yourself or you're looking at a month wait for an appointment and then I used to have to wait months between appointments. My GP, (General Practitioners here in England) was the one who helped me out, she referred me to a voluntary agency to get a support worker and we finally got medication that worked for me, she sees me every 2 weeks to see how the meds and everything else is going and even books me an appointment if I don't in time for it. It's scary to think other people might not seek this help too 😭😭😭 she's the glue to my whole treatment. Last month she noticed a dip in my mood and saw me 3 times that week. Specialists miss this.

snippet.textDisplay: It’s been over 60 years that the DSM handbook came out, yet there’s still no reliable test for chemical imbalance. Again, I’m only taking about people with mild anxiety/depression.

snippet.textDisplay:
You are truly an inspiration!
I love lady Gaga but I agree that she did a whoopsie with her sweeping statement.
The other thing it would be awesome if you could break down is the number of chronic vs acute mental health issues within that 1 in 5 adults. I think a lot of people tend to conflate a depressive episode with chronic depression, for example, and its important to understand the distinction to be able to adequately treat both.

I'm chronically depressed and on meds and therapy for it. I've had friends who were experience depressive episodes and when they came to me to ask about my meds the first thing I told them was to talk to a doc about CBT and talk therapy first. Any meds come with risks but it never hurts to get better at thinking straight!

snippet.textDisplay: I think there is a big difference between what a primary care doctor is capable (or should be capable) of doing and what many of them actually do. As a patient, my perception is that doctors are constantly being pressured to take on larger and larger case loads leaving less time for each individual patient. It is very rare that I find a doctor who is willing to spend more than 5 minutes doing anything with a patient, but patients are expected to spend upwards of an hour beyond their scheduled visit time waiting to be seen. I more than frequently feel as though I am just a number/statistic and that the doctor does not have any interest in treating me as an individual. I think a large problem is that patients do not feel like they are being heard/listened to and that causes patients to seek other options. In large cities, it can be difficult to get appointments with new doctors (without having to wait several months for an appointment) and to switch primary care providers due to limitations in insurance coverage and the ability to find doctors who are accepting new patients.

snippet.textDisplay: I kind of agree with gaga on this... family med dr prescribe antidepressants for everything without regard to particular diseases and are VERY bad at diagnosing mental illness. Not all, but a good majority, especially older dr. Psychologists just know way more about what they are doing, don't over prescribe, know more about drug classes and their effects, know the difference between mental and physical symptoms, etc. From my own personal experience family dr are really bad with handling this stuff and too quick to blame actual medical problems on mental illness. A family dr diagnosed me with panic attacks and it was years before I finally got diagnosed with asthma and it was because I had a bad attack, went to the ER and was seen by a lung dr who did tests where I breathed into a machine that checks lung capacity. My so called panic attacks completely disappeared once I was on asthma meds. Another time I was losing a lot of weight, getting constant kidney infections and having stomach pain. After scans and test came back normal for my kidney and intestines the dr I had then said I had some kind of eating disorder and that they would refuse to continue to treat me unless I took antidepressants and went to a psych. Months later I get in to a psych and they tell me its medical and switch doctors. I had to change dr twice before the problem was found, I had a uterine tumor the size of a cantelope that was partly blocking my digestive tract and urine from going out. I have medical anxiety and anxiety about needles. (similar to people who get anxious about the dentist) I explain this to any new dr but it often doesn't help, they think that because I am anxious in the dr office I MUST obviously have GAD and everything must be caused by anxiety but it couldn't be further from the truth...I avoid going to the dr unless an issue is so serious my concern over my health is enough to push through my fear and go to the dr. It is the most frustrating thing in the world.

snippet.textDisplay: I think it is important to remember that Lady Gaga suffers and has suffered from chronic illnesses, which is often treated by PCPs as a mental health issue rather than a physiological issue. As a result, most sufferers of chronic illness have been prescribed a range of mental health medications in lieu of actually being listened to, specifically by their PCP. While her stance here is, obviously, incorrect. There is a good chance she's coming from a point-of-view of possibly having lost a lot of trust for the medical system and PCPs, as many of us have experienced. And while there is a range of reasons, be it abuse or neglect, a general loss of faith with medicine and the capabilities of PCPs is an unfortunate side effect of that. Maybe it's not, maybe it really is just coming from a point of blank ignorance, but as a fellow sufferer of chronic illness I do have some sympathy with the fact she might not be entirely cool with the medical professionals who have treated both her chronic and mental health issues.
snippet.textOriginal: I think it is important to remember that Lady Gaga suffers and has suffered from chronic illnesses, which is often treated by PCPs as a mental health issue rather than a physiological issue. As a result, most sufferers of chronic illness have been prescribed a range of mental health medications in lieu of actually being listened to, specifically by their PCP. While her stance here is, obviously, incorrect. There is a good chance she's coming from a point-of-view of possibly having lost a lot of trust for the medical system *and* PCPs, as many of us have experienced. And while there is a range of reasons, be it abuse or neglect, a general loss of faith with medicine and the capabilities of PCPs is an unfortunate side effect of that. Maybe it's not, maybe it really is just coming from a point of blank ignorance, but as a fellow sufferer of chronic illness I do have some sympathy with the fact she might not be entirely cool with the medical professionals who have treated both her chronic and mental health issues.

snippet.textDisplay:
Doctor Mike, I just discovered your channel and am marathoning your videos. I really like your videos on nutrition and would like you to talk about the misdiagnosis and biases against fat people who go to the doctor. As an overweight person since I was little, I have been misdiagnosed, dismissed and told to lose weight, and even sneered at in the doctor's office. Growing up, it made me dread going to the doctor. I hated "failing" my doctor by continuing to be fat, despite my efforts. It makes you not want to go to the doctor at all.

It would mean the world to me. I know there are many studies that show long term (greater than 5 years) weight loss of more than 10lbs almost never happens AND evidence that fluctuating weight is worse than just being overweight. Could you weigh in on this (pun not intended)?

It would mean the world to me. I know there are many studies that show long term (greater than 5 years) weight loss of more than 10lbs almost never happens AND evidence that fluctuating weight is worse than just being overweight. Could you weigh in on this (pun not intended)?

snippet.textDisplay:
Opening statement: Doctors are highly trained professionals. Licensure demands are highly rigorous, and they are experts in caring for physical health. I truly believe that general practitioners or primary care physicians should be the first go to in prescribing any medicines including psychopharmacology. The following statements are not to undermine their expertise, nor to make others' question their ability. I think any general mistrust in doctors and medicine is misfounded, and harmful to society as a whole. This said, the comments below are to discuss limitations that I have experienced and feel should be addressed. They do not largely apply to every population, and are not aimed to discredit anyone.
I'm currently working on two Master's degrees in clinical psychology, and clinical mental health counseling. My only concern for what you're saying, Dr. Mike, is the stories I've heard from professors of even psychiatrists (trained in mental health medicine) giving antidepressants to individuals with bipolar disorder because of lack of assessment of manic symptoms. A client or patient is incredibly unlikely to come in during a manic episode, but will most definitely come in during a depressive one, so the doctor prescribes an antidepressant and suddenly the person is in the highest manic episode they've ever experienced. It's a serious problem that has led to devastating consequences, especially considering that individuals with bipolar tend towards lower SES's just due to the severity of the issue. You're incredibly right in that general practitioners need to be confident prescribing psychopharmacology, but how would you recommend resolving the issue outlined above? I'm also aware that this issue only affects a minimal percentage of the American population (only a few percentage points), but it is an issue regardless. Additionally, it highlights the lack of training that many physicians (even experts in the field) receive regarding mental health

The professors were recounting stories that had happened within the last five or so years to their own personal clients.

I had tried to explain that to my mom, that the risk of the treatment overshadowes the benifits of a clear diagnose in this case. It did not realy work. I'm in treatment for endometriosis, without a 100% solid diagnose. That is because you can only diagnose it without a doubt with a laparoscopie and this can worsen the condition more than just a little. My syptoms are realy no fun, but they don't indicate a need for a surgery. Yeah I have insane pain one week every month often acompanioned by dizzyness, nausea fainting or migrains . . . but I have only that. The pain is not constant way ot of this one week window, so no matter the pain level, I'm most likely a harmless case. So it would do more harm than good to do this surgery cause, well, I get a diagnose, but the cut tissue will just resurface somewhere else and beside taking out the tissue again and again and again and hormonal treat that only works as long as you take it and makes me feel even worse there is not realy a treatment. At the moment I fare better with managing my symptoms with lifestyl choices like diet and things like this.
She does not understand how young people can have uncurable non deadly conditions. If you are old, at some point it gets normal to have athrosis, that can't be reversed, or dementia or something like this but in young people . . .those are supposed to be healthy beside an occasional flue.

snippet.textDisplay:
When I was first getting help with my depression my primary care doc gave me a med she had a good track record with. After I didn’t respond to it she referred me to a psych and I kinda wish she hadn’t. It was a very very over worked mental health center that only saw me for about 10 minutes at a time. We cycled through different drugs. One worked and then stopped with the season change. Instead of working with me to adjust my dosage the specialist kept me trying different drugs. Once we went through the whole list she tried to change my diagnosis to bipolar, just to access a different med list instead of truly working with me. I questioned this, I have NEVER had any manic tendencies, but she wouldn’t listen to me so I stopped going.

I ended up adjusting my dosage myself with the one med that worked and figured how to change it with my SAD. I do not recommend this, it should’ve been done under the care of a doctor, I got lucky. I have since gotten luckier that my primary care docs know me well enough to agree to my dosage and work with me on it.

snippet.textDisplay: I totally agree with all of this; the primary care physician is so important in the treatment algorithm of mental health disorders. I also think it’s so important to get insight from pharmacists to help the primary care physician!! As a pharmacy student myself, we are literally trained about the in’s and out’s of hundreds of medications including antidepressants, anti-anxiety medications, and other psychiatric medications. And we know medications aren’t always the first step and that cognitive behavioral therapy and other non-pharmacological options are valid and useful in treatment of many disease states, including those related to mental health. The medical knowledge of pharmacists is often overlooked, but they are truly the medication experts and a great resource for physicians in treating all kinds of diseases!!

snippet.textDisplay: I think this stigma comes from a prior generation of PCPs who frankly were not trained to handle mental health issues. Lady Gaga is about my age so I wouldn't be shocked if she's had similar experiences with a PCP. My childhood family physician was an older gentleman who came up in a time where mental health issues were not discussed by ANYONE. And generally in those cases the doc either didn't acknowledge mental health issues at all, or wanted to put you on Xanax if you had a single bad day. He tried to put me on anti-depressants as a teenager because I was "moody." I was....a teenager. Who wasn't as giddily happy all the time as I had been as a five-year-old. And he wanted me on anti-depressants for that. So like...I get where LG is coming from a bit. Good to know PCPs now get educated on mental health though.

snippet.textDisplay: I have a question about the American Healthcare System. snippet.textDisplay: I know this is not the case all the time, but my family doctor told me I didn’t need therapy, I didn’t need meds, that I needed to get a job and be useful. I wasn’t eating because of depression and anxiety and he just gave me something to increase my appetite, I was sleeping all the time and was having physical pain. He didn’t help at all, I had to go to a psychiatrist and she gave me meds and send me to therapy. I’m so much better now and a little wary about trusting my mental health to any doctor that isn’t a mental health professional and I think that was why Gaga said that, maybe, I mean I know you shouldn’t generalize because of personal experience but some primary care doctors dismiss mental health so much, and it happens often enough to be worry about it.

snippet.textDisplay:
Thank you for bringing this to attention! I was hoping you would!!
My PCP prescribed me an antidepressant postpartum and it worked great when I needed to be taking it. I sought out my PCP because I trust her entirely and I've had her for quite some time. I didn't want to go to a psychiatrist, and I felt no need to. I am really disappointed Lady Gaga made that statement. It's very inaccurate and PCP's (in my opinion) can and sometimes should prescribe a medication over sending someone to a psychiatrist unless of course it's needed.

snippet.textDisplay: I dont know about other people's experience but where I live, there are almost no primary care practitioners that prescribe controlled substances like anti anxiety or ADHD medication.  A person must go to a psychiatrist.  Also my psychiatrist complains that the few who do prescribe these or are in a hospital setting often disregard his advice or give the wrong medication for the diagnosis.  So from my experience Lady Gaga is correct.

snippet.textDisplay:
Although I usually agree with you, I gotta disagree with you on this one. I do believe that family doctors are very capable of dealing with mental illnesses but they should not be prescribing antidepressants. When my doctor prescribed me some, I honestly almost died of serotonin syndrome. Apparently some liver enzymes (CYPs) are not doing their job and I was basically overdosing even though I took the dose that was prescribed. at least 3% of the caucasian race has this liver enzyme deficiency and it should be tested more often. It's just a simple blood test! The second antidepressant she prescribed got me very sick and I ended up in the hospital. Once she sent me to a psychiatrist, he noticed what was wrong and gave me the right medicine that my body does break down. It works like a charm.

Even though it's just a personal experience, I don't not recommend people to get antidepressants from there doctor. Being THAT close to death without having an actual disease at 16 is really traumatizing. 10/10 would not recommend.

snippet.textDisplay:
I've been moving around too much to build up a patient-doctor relationship with anyone I feel I can trust so I generally wait to go in anywhere until I can't stand the pain of whatever ailment I have.


Most recent example was it took me two days after a type four allergic reaction appeared on my hands, covering them with small white blisters and swelling the left one till I couldn't bend my fingers. The itching became unbearable so I showed up to the ER finally.
The blisters had started to appear on my wrist which was majorly annoying.
Long story short, definitely recommend seeing a doctor and taking/using the medicine/creams they give you instead of holding onto icecubes with your bare hands so the itching turns to pain instead. The medicine works a whole lot better.

snippet.textDisplay:
I get what you are saying, but I TOTALLY agree with lady Gaga’s statement. As someone that has been battling with depression and anxiety myself, I first went to a general practitioner and it was a huge mistake, as you guys ( as much as you think so) dont actually know the complexities of anti depressants and the human brain, as much as psychiatrist does. To prescribe the wrong medication to an individual after seeing them for 15 minutes is extremely harmful, and in my case and a lot more people I’ve been touch, nearly caused death.

Your advice is a BAD ADVICE.
